articles.headline: Harris Now Has an Economic Plan. Can It Best Trump’s Promises?
articles.snippet: A central question in the final stretch of the election is if Vice President Kamala Harris’s proposals will cohere into an economic argument that can top former President Donald J. Trump’s.
articles.abstract: A central question in the final stretch of the election is if Vice President Kamala Harris’s proposals will cohere into an economic argument that can top former President Donald J. Trump’s.
articles.lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris has a plan for the economy: a glossy, 82-page booklet detailing proposals on housing, taxes and health care that her campaign handed out to supporters gathered at a campaign event in Pittsburgh this week.
articles.byline: By Andrew Duehren and Jim Tankersley

articles.headline: Trump’s Plans Could Spur Inflation While Slowing Growth, Study Finds
articles.snippet: A nonpartisan economic analysis warned that deporting migrants and increasing tariffs would damage the U.S. economy.
articles.abstract: A nonpartisan economic analysis warned that deporting migrants and increasing tariffs would damage the U.S. economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump’s proposals to deport millions of migrants and impose new tariffs on imports from around the world would slash U.S. economic growth and employment and cause inflation to rebound sharply, according to a new analysis published on Thursday by the nonpartisan Peterson Institute for International Economics.

articles.headline: Harris Has a Lot of Strengths. Giving Interviews Isn’t One of Them.
articles.snippet: Vice President Kamala Harris is a sharp debater and a tireless campaigner, but televised interviews are a weakness. Her professional experience may explain why.
articles.abstract: Vice President Kamala Harris is a sharp debater and a tireless campaigner, but televised interviews are a weakness. Her professional experience may explain why.
articles.lead_paragraph: The first question Vice President Kamala Harris faced on Wednesday night, in her first solo interview with a major cable network as the Democratic presidential nominee, was posed as a gentle hypothetical: What would she say to the many Americans who do not see how her economic policies would serve them?

articles.headline: Netanyahu Defiant as World Leaders Press for Israeli-Hezbollah Truce
articles.snippet: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel vowed to keep striking the Lebanese militants, who began launching rockets across the border almost a year ago in support of their Hamas allies in Gaza.
articles.abstract: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel vowed to keep striking the Lebanese militants, who began launching rockets across the border almost a year ago in support of their Hamas allies in Gaza.
articles.lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said on Thursday that the Israeli military would keep striking Hezbollah militants in Lebanon with “all our might,” even as the United States, its European allies and several Arab states worked furiously to negotiate a three-week cease-fire.
articles.byline: By Liam Stack, Patrick Kingsley, Farnaz Fassihi and Michael Levenson

articles.headline: The Fed’s Preferred Inflation Gauge Cooled in August
articles.snippet: Inflation is slowing so much that some economists said it could pave the way for another big Fed rate cut, if other data suggest one is warranted.
articles.abstract: Inflation is slowing so much that some economists said it could pave the way for another big Fed rate cut, if other data suggest one is warranted.
articles.lead_paragraph: Inflation cooled in August, the latest sign of progress in the Federal Reserve’s yearslong fight to bring rapid price increases back under control.

articles.headline: Westminster Abbey’s Brontë Plaque Had a Typo for 85 Years. It’s Fixed Now.
articles.snippet: Punctuation delayed, but not denied: A memorial to Charlotte, Emily and Anne Brontë at Poets’ Corner in the celebrated London church finally gets its accent marks.
articles.abstract: Punctuation delayed, but not denied: A memorial to Charlotte, Emily and Anne Brontë at Poets’ Corner in the celebrated London church finally gets its accent marks.
articles.lead_paragraph: For 85 years, the names of three of English literature’s best-known writers, Charlotte, Emily and Anne Brontë, were featured in Poets’ Corner, the Westminster Abbey nook dedicated to great poets, authors and playwrights, but something wasn’t quite right: They were missing the accent mark.
